Award.AwardTitle: Vibrational and Electronic Properties of Complex Metal Oxides by Spectroscopic Ellipsometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronic and Photonic Materials (EPM) and Ceramic (CER) Programs in the Division of Materials Research.

NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This project trains students, including underrepresented minorities and women, in optical and X-ray thickness measurements of thin films (such as those used for advanced manufacturing in Rio Rancho, NM) and connects students with research at National Laboratories, especially the Center for Integrated Nanotechnologies at Sandia National Laboratories. The project determines the refractive index and absorption coefficient of novel crystalline oxides and studies the interaction of localized d- and f-electrons with atomic vibrations and itinerant s- and p-electrons in complex metal oxides. This research aims to develop new types of lasers and light detectors based on metal oxide heteroÂ¬structures.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project measures the optical constants of a broad range of complex metal oxides from the mid-infrared to the ultraviolet spectral region. The data is analyzed to draw conclusions on the vibrational, electronic, and transport properties of such oxides. Quantum confinement and stress effects in oxide heterostructures and intersubband transitions in oxide superlattices are also studied. Temperature is used a parameter to tune the oxide properties. Results are compared with theory to achieve a comprehensive understanding of correlated oxides. Experimental results provide adjustable parameters (such as the Hubbard U value) needed for band structure calculations. Undergraduate students engaged in this project visit local and regional high schools and perform materials physics classroom demonstrations. They also organize a week-long physics summer day camp in the New Mexico State University Physics Department.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The optical constants of a material include quantities such as the (complex) dielectric function, the refractive index, and absorption, extinction, and reflection coefficients. These quantities were determined in this project for several classes of materials (insulators, metals, and semiconductors) using an optical technique called spectroscopic ellipsometry, over a broad spectral range from the ultraviolet to the mid-infrared (190 to 40,000 nanometers) and at temperatures ranging from 10 to 800 degrees Kelvin. Knowledge of these optical constants is important for three reasons: (1) For optical materials, the optical constants are directly related to the performance of devices, such as optical filters, lasers, and detectors. (2) Optical techniques are used in advanced manufacturing, especially in the semiconductor industry, to measure thicknesses and line widths and for quality control. (3) The optical constants yield information about other materials properties, such as electrical conductivity, frequency of molecular vibrations (called phonons), or electronic band gaps and absorption thresholds.

Specifically, over a period of five years, this project investigated the optical constants of the following materials: The oxides of zinc, nickel, and permalloy; perovskites like strontium titanate, lanthanum aluminate, and lanthanum-strontium-aluminum-tantalum oxide (LSAT); semiconductors such as germanium, silicon carbide, and gallium phosphide; metals such as nickel and gold. Our most significant finding was the dependence of the optical constants of zinc oxide layers on the thickness and the substrate on which the layer was grown. These layers were produced by atomic layer deposition by collaborators at the Indian Institute of Technology in Indore. A similar result was found (but less conclusively) for strontium titanate layers on Si and Ge grown by molecular beam epitaxy. We also found that the broadening of the transverse optical phonon in oxides can be larger than the broadening of the related longitudinal phonon in the presence of two-phonon absorption. The temperature dependence of the optical constants of nickel could be described well with two species of charge carriers (s- and d-electrons). The main absorption peak in nickel is broadened by scattering with magnetic waves. An undergraduate student determined the temperature dependence of the optical constants of phase-change metal alloys based on germanium, antimony, and tellurium. This material system is of interest to NASA for mid-infrared filter applications in satellites to the planet Mars. Another mid-infrared detector material based on alloys of germanium and tin was also investigated. To describe the optical constants of the broad variety of these materials, a novel dispersion model was proposed. New digital filtering methods using Fourier transforms and Gaussian kernels were implemented and applied to the analysis of electron-hole correlation effects in germanium.

This project produced one Ph.D. thesis (by a student who now works at Intel) and two MS theses (one by a student who went on to a Ph.D. program). Three more Ph.D. theses are expected within the next twelve months. One Ph.D. student has accepted a postdoctoral position in Europe. The project also involved nine undergraduate students in this research. A series of YouTube videos on optical properties of solids was produced, based on a course on Advanced Optical Materials developed by the PI. The laboratory supported by this project was also used for an advanced capstone instructional laboratory course, which was crucial for the accreditation of the Bachelor of Science in Physics program at New Mexico State University by the applied and natural sciences commission of ABET, Inc. Students engaged in this project hosted several week-long physics summer day camps for local high school students. Results were disseminated in twenty-two peer-reviewed journal articles and ninety-seven conference presentations and posters (most of them given by students).

The PI and his graduate students collaborated internationally with a European high-power laser facility in the Czech Republic (ELI Beamlines) on the ultrafast processes in germanium and other semiconductors. A newly developed digital filtering was applied to the data obtained at this facility.
